summary: This is a DOJ Office of the Inspector General interview transcript from June 14, 2021, with a Federal Bureau of Prisons Correctional Officer Lieutenant (name redacted) regarding the death of inmate Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center. The interview focuses on staffing, procedures, communication failures, and the lieutenant's knowledge of Epstein's cellmate requirement prior to his death.

events.title: Epstein's prior suicide attempt
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found in his SHU cell after an apparent suicide attempt. The interviewed lieutenant responded and found him lying on the floor appearing unresponsive but breathing.

events.title: Email regarding cellmate requirement
events.description: Psychologist Darlene Imeri sent an email stating Epstein was being taken off psych observation and needed to be housed with an appropriate cellmate.

events.title: Removal of cellmate Efren Reyes
events.description: Inmate Efren Reyes, Epstein's cellmate, was removed from MCC for court and did not return, leaving Epstein without a required cellmate.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in his SHU cell at MCC. The interviewed lieutenant learned of the medical emergency after 7:00 a.m. and went to assist.

events.title: OIG Interview
events.description: DOJ OIG interview with an MCC lieutenant as part of the investigation into Epstein's death and surrounding circumstances.

keyFacts: The interviewed lieutenant stated she was unaware of the email requirement that Epstein needed a cellmate after coming off suicide watch, and believed the information should have been communicated verbally to all staff.
Staffing was critically low at MCC during this period, with correctional officers working 16+ hour days due to mandatory overtime and vacant posts.

The lieutenant expressed strong professional opinion that Epstein should have been placed in the maximum-security unit (10 South) from the beginning due to his high-profile status and prior suicide attempt.
There was confusion about the midnight count on August 10th because an inmate from SHU was being housed in R&D, leading to a count discrepancy that required correction.

The lieutenant stated there was no verification process to ensure COs actually conducted counts and rounds beyond taking their word, and supervisors were not required to visually verify inmate counts.
